BE

Following the UK vote to Brexit, we provide the earnings sensitivities of the European Pharma Large
Cap Companies to the FX moves as of 6.15am BST (7.15am CEST, 1.15am EST). With the GBP:USD
down 10%, EUR:USD down 4% and CHF:USD down -2% our analysis shows a significant benefit for
GSK Core EPS (denominated in GBP) of 6% and smaller benefit for AZN of 2%. We also see modest
benefits of c. 3% for the Continental Pharma names (Bayer and Novo) from the weakening Euro and
DKr. On fundamentals, we would expect GSK to significantly outperform both the FTSE 100
index and the European Large Cap Pharma Universe this morning. With very low UK and
cyclical topline exposure we believe GSK is likely to remain a core defensive holding in the UK.
We also expect the Large cap Pharma sector in general to Outperform today.

BE

BE

 GSK – GBP reporter, 4-5% UK revenue exposure, 22% EUR revenue exposure, heavy UK cost base. GSK report in GBP – costs largely unaffected, but USD and EUR revenues increase with the weak pound, therefore the potential impact on Core EPS is 6.0%.

Adjusting for the above assumptions, we calculate a 1.6% positive impact on Core Operating profit, as the GBP costs are lower in USD terms – but this is offset by lower EUR revenue in USD terms due to as a weakening of the EUR:GBP.

Yeah, first glance this morning, Taylor Wimpey was down more than 40%.

That's the UK's biggest housebuilder by volume.

BE

The UK being a market where houses are in structural undersupply that's unlikely to unwind for about five decades.

11:28 am
BE

And, at the margin, today could be seen to have strengthened the political will to support house prices at any cost.

BE

Worries about 1% off GDP and a slightly steeper interest rate path don't seem to justify 40% off Taylor Wimpey.

BE

(@roddy1234: thought it was Wimpey but they're pretty close, IIRC. Prepared to be wrong.)

11:29 am
BE

Here's Liberum on the sector.

BE

The debate over what the EU referendum means for the outlook for the UK will last much longer than today, but for now we offer the conclusion that the outcome is bad for housebuilders’ shares as the combination of slowing GDP, rising longer term rates and political uncertainty is like Kryptonite for that group of shares. Berkeley (HOLD), Crest Nicholson (NR), Barratt (HOLD) and Taylor Wimpey (HOLD) will fare worse than Persimmon (HOLD). PE/yield cross-over points happen 15-20% below last closing prices. UK exposed building material sectors will also face an adverse shock, especially those buying in components (like Howden (BUY)). Wolseley (BUY, TP 4100p) will be a unique beneficiary as a big overseas earner, with consensus EPS up around 7% at current spot rates.

BE

The "Leave" decision taken at the EU referendum makes the short to medium term outlook more difficult for housebuilders. Consensus expectations are likely to move to reflect slowing GDP growth, rising rates in the longer term and increased political uncertainty – a combination which is like Kryptonite for the high flying housebuilders. We would expect shares across our coverage to retest recent lows at best, some 13% lower than current levels for the housebuilders, and the sector could fall further if investors need bargain prices to attract a bid - we note that PE/yield cross-over points are 15-20% down from last night's close.

The stocks likely to perform worst are those with the highest selling prices and most London exposure, as these are where discretionary buyers are most likely to postpone decisions, notably Berkeley (HOLD) and Crest Nicholson (NR). Barratt (HOLD) and Taylor Wimpey (HOLD) have much more London and South East exposure than Persimmon (HOLD), which could mean that either of these make a logical pair choice in a fast moving environment.

11:29 am
BE

The fall in £ might make UK house prices look cheaper to overseas buyers, and short term rates may fall, but these are unlikely to be enough to improve buyers' appetite in the short term, given the step up in uncertainty over the outlook for the UK economy.

BE

It may be useful to point out that PE / yield crossover points (ie the point at which yields for 2017 exceed PERs occur at around 455p for Barratt (down 20%), 2700p for Berkeley (off 18%) and 163p for Taylor Wimpey (down 15%).

BE

And, oh, Canaccord I guess.

11:00 am
PM

This is Markets Live

BE

Merchants and Materials summary
While we see the Merchants also reacting negatively to the outcome of the referendum,
the sector has some offsetting currency impacts and ratings are generally not as high
relative to long run average valuation multiples as the house-builders. Wolseley, SIG,
Grafton and Tyman should enjoy significant offsetting positive currency translation
impacts. The end market most impacted by the EU vote uncertainty has been larger
Commercial projects being put on hold, which is particularly relevant for Marshalls and
Travis Perkins' Contracts business. 2017E sector PE is c.13.5 times.
Key stocks to highlight
In the near term, we expect house-builders with more London exposure to suffer the
sharpest falls. We would highlight Berkeley Group, Telford Homes, and Barratt in this
context. Among the Merchants, we would highlight the pure UK plays Travis Perkins and
Howdens as being most exposed to a weaker UK outlook.

PM

Tears For Tier 1: raises this ERM comparision. It's fair-ish -- but you have to remember that back then £ was catching up with reality; this time round it is just a new reality.

PM

Last week, we suggested four Brexit hedges which also doubled as investment strategies in the event of a Remain vote: 1) outcome agnostic, eg Tobacco/Oil, using safe dividends to buy out of money downside protection, 2) buybacks, ie aligning with (corporate) buyers when few are to be found, 3) strong balance sheet & surplus FCF US exposed stocks, and 4) The UK 7. The Referendum outcome makes all relevant for investors. Here we focus on "The UK 7".

BE

Experian?!

11:33 am
PM

These were 7 big Buy-rated UK stocks with high levels of non-European sales/profit exposure and hence positive sensitivity to potential GBP weakness. Given the asymmetric risk in GBP ahead of the Referendum, we saw these stocks as a good way to take advantage of this asymmetry in companies with positive fundamental support. The 7 are: BP, Shire, Diageo, GSK, BATs, HSBC, Experian. These 7 stocks offer investors an attractive yield, which we believe is better protected by a weaker GBP than threatened by weaker UK or Euro Area GDP growth.

BE

From housebuilders to property .......

11:38 am
BE

... and Mike Prew of Jefferies on the REITs.

BE

By which I mean office rents, really. Mike's always worth reading.

BE

We believe REITs will sell-off in proportion to their London office exposure.
Then it's the dysfunctional post BREXIT buyers market LAND CEO Rob Noel
predicted. Likely some sweaty palms among complacent REIT CEOs who ran
with the pollsters. Relocating 100k London jobs to Paris/Frankfurt removes
20 'Gherkins' of demand with the equivalent of 50 being built. We estimate
London office rents -18% and the sector -18% downside.

11:39 am
PM

(CommentGoesHere -- yes, when i last visited. spectacular food)

PM

(merkel's on the box)

BE

REITs sold off to 25%-30% discounts in mid-Feb (coinciding with BoJo throwing his

weight behind BREXIT) and the referendum debate then went ‘live’. DLN and GPOR sold off

-5% on the Monday (intraday so we expect at least the same again today) and since then

(with the exception of the first half of June when the sector sold off nearly -15% on Brexit odds greater than 50%). It's BREXIT and a big BREXIT vote with 24 June Independence Day, but even with a remain vote, we believe the UK real estate market was still facing a global growth slump. BREXIT leads to a London office paradox in that rents could fall by c.-18% as the 26m sq ft office development pipeline (visualize as 50 Gherkins’ - the iconic 516,000 sq ft building at 30 St Mary Axe, London, EC3) over the next 4 yrs feeds into the BREXIT demand shock. Our estimate is of 100,000 London jobs from International businesses HQ’d in the capital shifting to Continental Europe with the loss of their passporting rights into the EU which with av occupation densities (typically 100 sq ft per worker) removing 10m sq ft of
demand (20 'Gherkins'). Our rental forecast is for rents -18% but this adjustment could take 2 years post Article 50 being enacted. The positive is that the currency sell-off (-10% vs. -5% on Black Wednesday Sept 1992) could see overseas capital flow into long lease assets when the coupon is secure (i.e. if there isn’t a short term lease expiry to lower rents) as well as gilt yields falling. It’s a complex yield story given that the BOE has already pledged emergency liquidity measures including cutting rates.

11:40 am
BE

We expect a sharp correction in REITs roughly in proportion to their portfolio London office content with no excuses for valuers to peg portfolio valuations to the high water mark of the last trade that printed. Retail remains remarkably under demolished (Sell HMSO esp. with its Scottish mall exposure and INTU post its discounted Merry Hill tranche purchase and other secondary retail plays e.g. NRR, CNR). The sell-off will focus on liquid names LAND & BLND (roughly half and half London offices/retail) and the MidCap London office developer specialists DLN and GPOR will be friendless (similar to 2001 after the TMT bubble burst and tech businesses are driving 40% of demand in the West End and City fringes). If you have to be in the sector then we believe the best exposure is probably the industrials with 'Sheds the new Shops' (SGRO, LMP, BBOX) and sub-sectors where demand is likely to remain sturdy: student housing (UTG, ESP – only 5% of student numbers are from the EU ex UK) and self- storage (BYG, SAFE as modern flats have no storage) while the collapse in the land market for high rise, high density London residential towers almost inevitable (CAPC, SMP).

PM

(Tears For Tier 1 -- we have their full support!)

PM

(but no, this isn't good for press advertising)

11:41 am
BE

Once the UK economy returns to growth (after a 2yr mild recession but HMT and BoE would openly welcome a weaker exchange rate, permanently, especially in a world where UK trade is turning down) then remember real estate does well in a low inflation environment (you get the yield advantage unless its deflation and your tenants go bust), and in high inflation (you get an equity kicker from coupon with rental growth). The worst economic outcome is something febrile in the middle which we believe is likely to be the best possible outcome unless base rates go German (i.e. turn negative), which is always a possibility. We expect London will ultimately end up being less successful and it will be different. Since August 2015 (see Punctuated Equilibrium: Sector Downgrades) we have had av. real estate values falling -5% in 2017, total returns of 0% and NAVs falling -5% to -7% in 2016/17 and we have kept our bottom of the range PTs (see pg 2) with av. -18% downside which is where we capture the BREXIT risk. After all, we've known about it since May 2015.

easyJet's initial focus will be to accelerate discussions with UK and EU governments and regulators to ensure that the UK remains part of the single EU aviation market. This would enable EU airlines to fly freely within the UK and between the UK and EU, allow UK airlines to fly freely across Europe and would ensure that consumers continue to benefit from low fares and would mean easyJet and other airlines can continue to operate as they do now. easyJet will also continue to develop its alternative options that will fully maintain its existing network and operations.

PM

"We remain confident in the strength of easyJet's business model and our ability to continue to deliver our successful strategy and our leading returns. We have today written to the UK Government and the European Commission to ask them to prioritise the UK remaining part of the single EU aviation market, given its importance to trade and consumers."

11:50 am
BE

But .... well, who knows. Here's Barclays to make a stab at it.

BE

FX and hedges first.

BE

· Ryanair: Implied downside of 6% in net profit. We estimate Ryanair has c25% revenue in GBP, vs 10% of costs. Ryanair has said that a 1ppt move in GBP/EUR is worth €15m on net income, so at current spot this would be a €90m headwind, or 6% on EPS. Ryanair also has a large short dollar position, although this is very well hedged, both on opex and capex, and the EUR/USD moves have been minor so far. We do not see risk to Ryanair’s FY17 guidance.

· easyJet: Implied 7% EBIT downside unhedged, protected by hedges on USD in short term. Reporting in GBP, easyJet is long euro (40% of revenue vs 32% of costs) so technically benefits from this position. However, it has a much more significant USD short position. The USD position is fully hedged for the next 12-18 months, but on an unhedged basis the overall implied impact to EBIT is 7%. easyJet also has rising USD capex commitments over the next few years. easyJet has not yet given explicit FY16 profit guidance.

11:50 am
BE

2) Demand implications. The longer term impact of a ‘Leave’ vote on underlying air travel demand is uncertain, with various potential ‘second order’ effects. Our economics team’s exit scenario sees a marked slowdown in UK GDP, the brunt of which felt by business investment. Amongst our coverage, easyJet has the highest UK point-of-sale exposure (~50%) followed by IAG (~35%). IAG clearly has more sensitivity to corporate capex, but a fall in sterling may also suppress outbound UK leisure travel. On a relative basis, Ryanair and Wizz Air would appear at less risk, given: (i) negligible corporate exposure, and (ii) more balanced point-of-sale between UK and Continental Europe.

3) Regulatory framework likely to remain in place. At present the UK has full flying rights within the European ‘open skies’ zone (ECAA), including ‘seventh freedoms’, which allow UK airlines to operate between two other EU countries (for example, easyJet services between Spain and Italy) which will continue in the event of ‘Remain’ outcome. In the event of a ‘Leave’ vote, we think it is highly likely that the UK would attempt to negotiate with all parties to keep the status quo and remain a full member of the ECAA, similar to Norway. A less likely alternative, as adopted by Switzerland, would be to sign a bilateral with the ‘new EU’, which might not cover seventh freedoms. In this case, easyJet would likely need to establish a separate legal entity within the ‘new EU’, while, conversely, Ryanair and Wizz might require a UK entity. These sort of structures are certainly feasible.

Uncertainties remain with the outcome of the EU vote, and with such a lack of clarity we
expect the sector to be sharply de-rated and to remain volatile.
While the sector is in good shape in terms of having strong balance sheets and showing
capital discipline, it will continue to face the following risks with this Brexit vote: 1)
a sharp fall in net migration and therefore future household formation trends, 2) a
reduction in labour supply and increase in labour costs, and 3) a negative macro shock
on GDP and particularly unemployment. For us, the most significant near-term risk is
that unemployment increases and/or mortgage availability deteriorates, which would
inevitably hit confidence and housing demand.
Recent sales rates and estimates have held up generally well into the EU referendum
so we would see the biggest risk to consensus estimates in the near term being from
weaker sales rates and the impact on house price inflation.
We expect share prices to react very negatively today to the continued lack of visibility in
relation to the medium-term demand and supply drivers of the housing market and risks
of a potential macro slowdown. Sentiment will likely deteriorate materially for such a UK
domestic sector. The extent of potential share price falls is also likely to be exacerbated
by the strong rally the sector enjoyed over the last few days as the likelihood of a Brexit
vote was believed to have diminished. Valuation multiples are not pricing in much risk of
a Brexit outcome. On a 2017E P/NAV multiple of c.1.9 times and PE of c.9 times, 2016E
valuation metrics are broadly as they traded on average during 2015. Consequently,
our best guess would be that the sector sees double-digit percentage falls and under-
performs the wider market.
